text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 7.11.2, Employee Plans Determinations Letter Program, EP Case Assignment Guide.
Updated throughout for editorial and plain language changes.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 7.11.2 dated August 20, 2019.
Tax Exempt and Government Entities Employee Plans
Table of Contents

Audience: EP Determinations, Examination and VC staff.

) The procedures for grading Determination, Examination and VC cases are described below. (
) When a Determination Letter (DL) application is input onto the Tax Exempt termination System (TEDS), the applicable program assigns a potential case grade by applying the criteria in IRM
, EP Determination Case Grading Criteria. (
) EP Determinations specialists and Group Managers may change the case grade, if necessary, by applying the case grade adjustment factors in IRM
, Case Grade Adjustments. (
) EP Classiﬁcation assigns a potential grade to examination cases though a variety of tools. They apply the criteria in IRM
, EP Examination Case Grading Criteria, to cases in combination with information from RICS, RCCMS and other tools. (
) The EP classiﬁer or Group Manager should adjust the case grade, if

EP Classiﬁcation assigns a potential grade to examination cases though a variety of tools. They apply the criteria in IRM 7.11.2.6, EP Examination Case Grading Criteria, to cases in combination with information from RICS, RCCMS
The EP classiﬁer or Group Manager should adjust the case grade, if
necessary, by applying the case grade adjustment factors in IRM
, Case Grade Adjustments. Compliance (
) The VC screening groups assign case grades to VC applications by applying the criteria in IRM
, EP Voluntary Compliance Case Grading Criteria. (
) During the processing of the VC case, the grade can be adjusted, using the factors in IRM
, Case Grade Adjustments, if the case requires addi- tional technical analysis. (
) The grade of the VC case is not affected by the case grade of any DL applica- tion that may have been submitted with respect to the plan. Assignment (
) Determination, Examination and VC cases should generally be assigned to specialist/agent whose grade is commensurate with the grade of the case. (

) Related plan cases should be assigned to a specialist/agent whose grade is commensurate with the highest grade of the cases involved. However, this rule is not applicable to situations involving VC cases that have a related DL application. Example: A GS-
case and a related GS-
case should be assigned to a GS-
specialist/agent. However, if a GS-
VC case is associated with a GS-
DL application, both cases do not have to be assigned to a GS-
specialist/agent. (

) Specialists/agents may be assigned cases above their grade level for develop- mental purposes. a. Group Managers are responsible for keeping developmental assignments within the limits stated by the current National Agreement. b. Assignment of developmental cases is governed by local circumstances. (

) Group Managers may assign a lower-graded case to a higher-graded specialist/agent if the potential impact of the case is signiﬁcant or to meet erational needs. Such assignments do not raise the case grade. (

) To the extent that staffing considerations permit, appropriate measures should be taken to avoid consecutive assignment of cases that violates any of the following restrictions: a. With respect to determination case assignments, the same specialist should not review the same employer’s plan more than two times in cession to the extent possible. This should not be construed as meaning that a specialist could not review several plans of an employer at the same time. Using these measures will minimize the possibility of over- looking errors in plan design. b. Any plan that is part of the team audit program (formerly the Coordinated Examination Programs) should be a grade

case. c. With respect to VC cases, the same VC specialist/agent should not review the same employer’s plan more than two times in succession to the extent possible. This should not be construed as meaning that a specialist/agent could not review several plans of an employer at the same time. Using these measures will minimize the possibility of over-
necessary, by applying the case grade adjustment factors in IRM 7.11.2.6.1, Case Grade Adjustments.

) Some factors that may increase the case grade include failures relating a. Funding and actuarial matters. b. Asset valuation issues (for example, investments in limited partnerships). c. Prohibited transactions. d. Unrelated business income. e. Complex IRC
issues. f. Nondiscrimination issues (for example, GT, aggregation, restructuring, cross testing). g. Exclusive beneﬁt. (
) Other factors that may increase the case grade include: a. Signiﬁcant complications caused by the IRC
(b), (c) and (n) rules. b. Coordination with the Department of Labor (DOL) and/or Pension Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). (
) Factors that may decrease the case grade include: a. Involvement of the ﬁeld actuary, OJI, senior agent, or Group Manager. b. Complicating issues not found. c. Case impact is limited, e.g., a

-EZ return, or a minor adjustment. d. Agent’s review doesn’t include complicating issues justifying the higher grade. For example, a focused audit where the higher graded issues aren’t considered during the course of the examination. Voluntary Case Criteria (

Factors include plans described below for Grade

(all plans). a. Any VC case where the review is limited to an inspection of the submitted materials to determine whether the case is complete and satisﬁed the administrative requirements under the EPCRS revenue procedure. b. Any VC case assigned to VC personnel where the sole purpose is to collect missing or incomplete items from the VCP applicant in order to perfect submissions that are otherwise not in compliance with the admin- istrative requirements under the EPCRS revenue procedure. Examples include, but are not limited to, missing Model VCP Submission Compli- ance statement schedules, incorrect signatures, missing or unsigned penalty of perjury statements, missing enclosures, missing or incorrect compliance fees. c. Any VC case assigned where the VC Group Manager, or VC Program Coordinator, or higher graded specialist/agent has indicated the submis- sion can be closed, and the actions left to be taken are limited to the administrative actions needed to close the VC case.
) Grade Adjustments (

) Factors that may increase the case grade include failure(s) and/or correction methods relating to: a. The size of the plan. b. Actuarial issues in DB plans, including failures to comply with the restric- tions imposed by IRC
in operation. c. Nondiscrimination issues (for example, GT, aggregation, restructuring, and cross testing). d. Complex IRC

issues. e. Exclusive beneﬁt requirements. f. The number of errors identiﬁed or multiple years of the same error. g. Correction proposal that isn’t a correction method described in Appendix A or B of the EPCRS revenue procedure. h. Proposed correction method that involves a retroactive plan amendment to change the plan terms to conform to plan operation. i. Whether the cases will be or has the potential to close through use of Closing Agreement outside of EPCRS (via Delegation Order
). j. The relative sensitivity of the case, which can be affected by public scrutiny, DOL Investigations, potential fraud, and situations deemed by the IRS. (

) Factors that may decrease the case grade include: a. Signiﬁcant involvement of a ﬁeld actuary, OJI, VC Group Manager, VC Program Coordinator, or senior agent/specialist. b. Specialist review that does not include complicating issues justifying higher grade. c. Failure(s) corrected in accordance with the correction methods listed Appendix A or B of the EPCRS revenue procedure. Case Assignment Guide

Factors that may increase the case grade include failure(s) and/or correction methods relating to:
a. The size of the plan. b. Actuarial issues in DB plans, including failures to comply with the restric- tions imposed by IRC
in operation. c. Nondiscrimination issues (for example, GT, aggregation, restructuring, and cross testing). d. Complex IRC

issues. e. Exclusive beneﬁt requirements. f. The number of errors identiﬁed or multiple years of the same error. g. Correction proposal that isn’t a correction method described in Appendix A or B of the EPCRS revenue procedure. h. Proposed correction method that involves a retroactive plan amendment to change the plan terms to conform to plan operation. i. Whether the cases will be or has the potential to close through use of a Closing Agreement outside of EPCRS (via Delegation Order
). j. The relative sensitivity of the case, which can be affected by public scrutiny, DOL Investigations, potential fraud, and situations deemed abusive by the IRS.

Specialist review that does not include complicating issues justifying higher grade. Failure(s) corrected in accordance with the correction methods listed in Appendix A or B of the EPCRS revenue procedure.
Employee Plans Determination Letter Program
Manager Duties (

) The Group Manager may adjust the grade level upward or downward. Such changes should be based on factors not otherwise accounted for or accurately evaluated in the EP Case Assignment Guide. Note: Reasons for changing the case grade upward or downward include, for example: an expectation that special or complex problems will be encoun- tered; a combination of issues which impact on the complexity of the case; or, the scope of the review is limited. (
) For a case which can’t be graded using IRM
, EP Determination Case Grading Criteria, IRM
, EP Examination Case Grading Criteria or, IRM
, EP Voluntary Compliance Case Grading Criteria, Group Managers should determine which grade level most appropriately matches the case diffi- culty. (

) The Group Manager is responsible for ensuring the ﬁnal case grade is appro- priate based upon all of the facts and circumstances. Example: Before closing a case, the Group Manager may adjust the case grade upward, if complicating factors were found during review, or downward, anticipated complexities did not develop. (
) Refer to IRM
, Case Assignment Requirements, for more on the Group Manager’s responsibility with respect to case assignment. Responsibilities (

) The EP specialist/agent should notify the Group Manager immediately upon the discovery of a feature/issue which may result in an increase or decrease of the grade level. Until the manager approves the change, the case grade will not be considered changed.
tered; a combination of issues which impact on the complexity of the case; or, the scope of the review is limited. (
) For a case which can’t be graded using IRM
, EP Determination Case Grading Criteria, IRM
, EP Examination Case Grading Criteria or, IRM
, EP Voluntary Compliance Case Grading Criteria, Group Managers should determine which grade level most appropriately matches the case diffi- culty. (
) The Group Manager is responsible for ensuring the ﬁnal case grade is appro- priate based upon all of the facts and circumstances.
The Group Manager is responsible for ensuring the ﬁnal case grade is appro- priate based upon all of the facts and circumstances.
Example: Before closing a case, the Group Manager may adjust the case grade upward, if complicating factors were found during review, or downward, if anticipated complexities did not develop.
Refer to IRM 7.11.2.4, Case Assignment Requirements, for more on the Group Manager’s responsibility with respect to case assignment.

) The EP specialist/agent should notify the Group Manager immediately upon the discovery of a feature/issue which may result in an increase or decrease of the grade level. Until the manager approves the change, the case grade will not be considered changed.
